content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. An MA organization can only remove a provider from a plan network for reasons not specified in the Act after a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The MA plan removal process requires a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The process mandates the MA organization to explain the reasons for removing a provider from the network. The fair notice and appeal process for removing a provider from an MA plan network applies instead of the termination process outlined in section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations. The process for removing a provider from an MA plan network before the effective date follows the termination process outlined in section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations. The MA organization must notify participants at least 60 days before removing a provider from the network of an MA plan. The organization must provide written notification to individuals enrolled in the plan about the removal of a provider, including names and contact information of in-network providers. Additionally, an annual notice of change must be provided. The MA organization offering an MA plan must include notification of provider removal in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year to ensure continuity of care for individuals enrolled in the plan. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider provider availability when establishing a plan network, taking into account anticipated enrollment. When establishing a plan network, Medicare Advantage organizations must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and location of providers and enrollees. Medicare Advantage organizations must ensure timely provision of care by providers in their plan networks, as defined by the Secretary. The network access adequacy must consider factors like provider availability and location of providers and enrollees. Medicare Advantage organizations must certify timely provision of care by providers in their plan networks, seeking input from various stakeholders to apply network access adequacy standards. Medicare Advantage organizations must ensure that providers in their plan networks can offer required services and meet enrollees' needs, reporting annually to the Secretary for each MA plan offered. Advantage organization must report to the Secretary on each MA plan, including average wait times for care, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient. Providers under the Medicare Advantage plan must certify the accuracy of provider directories to the Secretary. The Secretary will review the network to ensure compliance. The Secretary ensures provider directories' accuracy and reviews the network of Medicare Advantage plans for compliance with network adequacy guidelines every 3 years or when a material change occurs. Enforcement is outlined in the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include enforcement measures for Medicare Advantage plans regarding network changes.
